content: Increased average fuel economy standards. Increased average fuel economy standards are amended to include non-passenger automobiles based on vehicle attributes related to fuel economy. The amendment includes non-passenger automobiles in the average fuel economy standards, ensuring a minimum of 27.5 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and beyond. The Secretary will set fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles at a minimum of 27.5 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and beyond. The Secretary sets average fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles each model year, based on maximum feasible levels achievable by manufacturers. Separate standards may be prescribed for different classes of passenger automobiles. The Secretary sets average fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles each model year, based on maximum feasible levels achievable by manufacturers. Separate standards may be prescribed for different classes of passenger automobiles. The average fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles manufactured for model year 2022 and beyond must be at least 35 miles per gallon. The average fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles manufactured for model year 2022 and beyond must be not less than 35 miles per gallon. Additionally, there will be an alternative minimum standard for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles. The Secretary will prescribe average fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles based on vehicle attributes. Manufacturers must meet an alternative minimum standard for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles, set at either 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for all fleets sold in the United States. The alternative minimum standard for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles is set at either 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for all fleets sold in the United States. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act, with a transition period for passenger automobiles to comply with either an attribute-based standard or a single corporate average fuel economy level. The standards for passenger automobiles under section 32902(b) of title 49, United States Code, will remain in effect until a new standard is prescribed. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a credit transferring program for manufacturers to transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet to comply with standards. Manufacturers can transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet to comply with standards. Credits can be applied to a compliance category of automobiles that fail to meet standards, with a maximum increase of 1.0 mile per gallon in any single model year. Manufacturers can transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet to comply with standards. The maximum increase in any compliance category is 1.0 mile per gallon in any single model year. Transfers of credits are limited to ensure compliance with fuel economy levels for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles. "In transfers of credits to the category of automobiles, the fuel economy level of domestically manufactured passenger automobiles must comply with established provisions. Credits can only be transferred if earned in model year 2010 or later." "In transfers of credits to the category of automobiles, the fuel economy level of domestically manufactured passenger automobiles must comply with established provisions. Credits can only be transferred if earned in model year 2010 or later. The term 'fleet' refers to all automobiles manufactured by a manufacturer in a specific model year, while the term 'compliance category of automobiles' includes passenger automobiles manufactured domestically." The term 'compliance category of automobiles' refers to the 3 categories for compliance calculation: domestically manufactured passenger automobiles, passenger automobiles not manufactured domestically, and non-passenger automobiles. SEC. 3. FUEL CONSERVATION EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary of Transportation will partner with industry groups to create a public education campaign on fuel conservation for US drivers. The campaign will use various methods to reach a wide audience. The public information campaign on fuel conservation for US drivers will be accessible through various methods and cost sharing will be limited to 50% of the campaign's cost. Private funds can also be accepted to supplement the campaign. The Secretary of Transportation will provide up to 50% of the cost for a fuel conservation campaign for drivers, with the option to accept private funds. Appropriations will be made as needed for this initiative.
